title: Three anti-social skills to improve your writing - Nadia Kalman

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "anti-social skills" in the context of writing dialogue?

options.label: A
options.text: Making friends and being pleasant with people.

options.label: B
options.text: Using skills that help writers to observe and imitate real-life conversations.

options.label: C
options.text: Using skills that help writers to create fictional conversations and characters.

options.label: D
options.text: Being rude and impolite to others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first anti-social skill that the speaker mentions for writing effective dialogue?

options.label: B
options.text: Muttering to yourself to test the sound of your dialogue.

options.label: D
options.text: Writing lengthy speeches for your characters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second anti-social skill that the speaker mentions for writing effective dialogue?

options.label: B
options.text: Muttering to yourself to test the sound of your dialogue.

options.label: D
options.text: Writing fictional dialogue that sounds like real conversations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third anti-social skill that the speaker mentions for writing effective dialogue?

options.label: C
options.text: Muttering to yourself to test the sound of your dialogue.

options.label: D
options.text: Writing lengthy speeches for your characters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on using adverbs in dialogue?

options.label: A
options.text: Use as many adverbs as possible to describe your characters' speech.

options.label: B
options.text: Use adverbs to describe the tone or emotion behind your characters' words.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid using adverbs and let the dialogue speak for itself.

options.label: D
options.text: Use adverbs to describe the setting or background of your story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on the length of dialogue?

options.label: A
options.text: Write long, lengthy speeches for your characters.

options.label: B
options.text: Keep your dialogue short and to the point.

options.label: C
options.text: Use as many words as possible to describe your characters' speech.

options.label: D
options.text: Use contractions to make your dialogue sound more natural.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on the tone of dialogue?

options.label: A
options.text: Use adverbs to describe the tone or emotion behind your characters' words.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid using adverbs and let the dialogue speak for itself.

options.label: C
options.text: Use contractions to make your dialogue sound more natural.

options.label: D
options.text: Write long, lengthy speeches for your characters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on the use of contractions in dialogue?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoid using contractions and write out full words instead.

options.label: B
options.text: Use contractions to make your dialogue sound more natural.

options.label: C
options.text: Use as many contractions as possible to describe your characters' speech.

options.label: D
options.text: Use contractions to describe the setting or background of your story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on the use of dialogue in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Use dialogue to describe the setting or background of your story.

options.label: B
options.text: Use dialogue to describe your characters' thoughts or feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: Use dialogue to advance the plot or conflict of your story.

options.label: D
options.text: Use dialogue to make your story sound more natural and realistic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to hear voices in your head?

options.label: A
options.text: Use your imagination to create fictional characters and conversations.

options.label: B
options.text: Eavesdrop on real-life conversations to get ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: Pretend imaginary people are real to get into character.

options.label: D
options.text: Mutter to yourself to test the sound of your dialogue.

title: How Caffeine Works

options.label: C
options.text: It increases energy levels by stimulating the production of adrenaline.

options.label: D
options.text: It blocks the production of adrenaline.

title: Why do wings help you fly?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why a wing generates lift?

options.label: B
options.text: Because air travels farther over top of the wing.

options.label: C
options.text: Due to the deflection of air downwards.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the pressure difference created by Bernoulli's principle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the simple explanation of how a wing works that is often taught in textbooks and classrooms?    - A: It is too complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: It does not explain how a plane can fly upside down.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not explain how air flows over the wing.

multiple-choice.question: According to Bernoulli's principle, what happens to the pressure of air that flows faster?    - A: It increases.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the coanda effect?    - A: The effect of air flowing faster over the top of the wing.

options.label: B
options.text: The effect of air being deflected downwards by the wing.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect of air being guided along the surface of the wing and down.

options.label: D
options.text: The effect of air being pushed up and back by the wing.

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Third Law of Motion, what happens to the wing when air is slowed and deflected down by it?    - A: It is pushed up and back.

options.label: B
options.text: It is pushed down and forward.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the wing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the Bernoulli explanation and the Newtonian explanation of how a wing generates lift?    - A: The Bernoulli explanation is more complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: The Bernoulli explanation assumes that air over and under the wing must reconnect at the trailing edge.

options.label: C
options.text: The Newtonian explanation assumes that air over and under the wing must reconnect at the trailing edge.

options.label: D
options.text: The Newtonian explanation is more accurate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct explanation of how a wing generates lift?    - A: Only the Bernoulli explanation.

options.label: C
options.text: Both the Bernoulli explanation and the Newtonian explanation.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither the Bernoulli explanation nor the Newtonian explanation.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the original explanation of how a wing works incorrect?    - A: Because it is too simple.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it does not explain how a plane can fly upside down.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it incorrectly assumes that air over and under the wing must reconnect at the trailing edge.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the wing of the Wright brothers' plane and a modern wing?    - A: The shape of the wing.
What is the purpose of a cambered airfoil?    - A: To increase the size of the wing.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the angle of attack.

title: How does digestion work?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to large molecules from food in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: They are absorbed into the blood plasma and lymph and transported to where the body can use them.

options.label: B
options.text: They are broken down into smaller molecules and then absorbed.

options.label: C
options.text: They are excreted from the body.

options.label: D
options.text: They are stored in the stomach.

multiple-choice.question: What are enzymes in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: Biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions.

options.label: B
options.text: Biological inhibitors that slow down chemical reactions.

options.label: C
options.text: Biological receptors that bind to food molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: Biological transporters that move molecules across cell membranes.

multiple-choice.question: Where are digestive enzymes produced in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: In specialized cells in glands and the lining of the gut.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of amylase in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol.

options.label: C
options.text: To break down starch into sugars.

options.label: D
options.text: To break down DNA into RNA.

multiple-choice.question: Where is amylase produced in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: In the pancreas, saliva glands, and small intestine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of lipase in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down starch into sugars.

options.label: C
options.text: To break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol.

options.label: D
options.text: To break down DNA into RNA.

multiple-choice.question: Where is lipase produced in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: In the pancreas and small intestine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH value of the stomach?
What is the function of bile in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol.

options.label: C
options.text: To neutralize stomach acid and create alkaline conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb nutrients into the bloodstream.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Gerrymandering: How drawing jagged lines can impact an election - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is gerrymandering?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of giving one political party an advantage over another by redrawing district lines.

options.label: B
options.text: The process of packing voters into one district to dilute their influence.

options.label: C
options.text: The process of cracking a district into several pieces to spread out voters.

options.label: D
options.text: The process of drawing district lines to favor a specific party's ideology.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with starting the practice of gerrymandering?

options.label: A
options.text: Elbridge Gerry, the governor of Massachusetts.

options.label: B
options.text: Thomas Jefferson, the president of the United States.

options.label: C
options.text: Abraham Lincoln, the president of the United States.

options.label: D
options.text: George Washington, the first president of the United States.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for packing voters into one district to dilute their influence?

options.text: group of voters who support a specific issue.

options.label: C
options.text: group of voters who are spread out across several districts.

options.label: D
options.text: group of voters who are packed into one district.

options.label: B
options.text: To spread out their opponent's voters and gain an advantage.

options.label: C
options.text: To pack their own voters into one district and gain an advantage.

options.label: D
options.text: To crack their own voters into several districts and gain an advantage.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Abraham Lincoln, the president of the United States.

options.label: D
options.text: George Washington, the first president of the United States.
